head.title: Academy Announces Winners of Rome Prize

hedline.hl1: Academy Announces Winners of Rome Prize

abstract.p: American Academy in Rome, center for independent study, research and creative work in arts and humanities, announces winners of annual Rome Prize Competition; list (M)

block.p: The winners of the annual Rome Prize Competition have been announced by the American Academy in Rome, a center for independent study, research and creative work in the arts and humanities.
The prizes are administered by the academy at its headquarters in Manhattan and include stipends and living and working accommodations on the academy's Rome campus for six months to two years.
The winners of the annual Rome Prize Competition have been announced by the American Academy in Rome, a center for independent study, research and creative work in the arts and humanities.
The prizes are administered by the academy at its headquarters in Manhattan and include stipends and living and working accommodations on the academy's Rome campus for six months to two years.
The winners will join the art historian Areli Marina and the classicist Ann Marie Yasin, who will complete the second and final year of their fellowships.
The academy is supported by private donations and by the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities and the United States Department of Education.
These are the 2000-01 winners:
Architecture Michael Goorevich, Cleveland Richard Taransky, Haddonfield, N.J.
Design Arts Lisa Krohn, Los Angeles Michael Palladino, Los Angeles
Historic Preservation and Conservation Elizabeth Walmsley, Washington Deirdre Windsor, Dover, Mass.
Landscape Architecture Mark Klopfer, Cambridge, Mass. David Meyer, Berkeley, Calif.
Literature Sigrid Nunez, New York
Musical Composition Michael Hersch, Forest Hills, Queens Pierre Jalbert, Stafford, Tex.
Visual Arts Dara Friedman, Miami Beach and New York Lyle Ashton Harris, New York Gary Hill, Seattle Donald Lipski, Sag Harbor, N.Y.
Classical Studies and Archaeology Leslie Dossey, Chicago John Curtis Franklin, London Karen E. Klaiber, New Brunswick, N.J. Carlos F. Norena, Philadelphia Andrew Zissos, Austin, Tex.
History of Art Jennifer R. Bethke, Berkeley, Calif. Charles M. Rosenberg, South Bend, Ind. Stefanie Walker, New York
Postclassical Humanistic/Modern Italian Studies Joanna H. Drell, Richmond, Va. Michael R. Ebner, New York H. Darrel Rutkin, Bloomington, Ind.

Correction: May 11, 2000, Thursday A brief article on Monday about the Rome Prize Competition in the arts and humanities, administered by the American Academy in Rome, omitted one winner. She is Wendy Heller, assistant professor of music at Princeton, who received the Mellon Post-Doctoral Research Fellowship.
